reviewText: This was a difficult film to review because although it is generally pretty bland there are some aspects I really liked and some I found awful.  Overall I couldn't give it more than 2 stars.Basically, it's a simple action picture about the America's Cup - good solid B-grade material.  The acting is passable, although the actors are weighed down with a terrible script that is full of cliches and stereotypes.  There is no imagination to the characterisation and the film never really engages the viewer.The scenes of sailing are, however, very well filmed and do capture the feeling of yacht racing, and the climax is suitably exciting and satisfying.  Unfortunately the rest of the film is so slow and so full of silly characters and dreadful dialogue that it makes the good bits hardly worth waiting for.But there is one great flaw in this film, and it is unforgivable.  A film such as this can contain fictional characters instead of the actual people who participated in the events, and it can even fictionalise events to a certain degree.  It is essential, however, that major events and characters are not altered because it is these that anchor the film to reality.  Change something important and the film becomes fantasy instead of adventure in an historical setting.For example, suppose the plot of Ron Howard's film "Apollo XIII" had the astronauts land on the moon and then the accident that crippled the ship occur on the return leg of the voyage.  The viewer would know that they were no longer watching historical drama, but science fiction instead.Well, that's what "Wind" does.  The director never seems to be able to decide whether they were creating a drama about the actual loss and subsequent win of the America's Cup by US teams in the 1980s, or whether they wanted to make a fictional story.For example, in early scenes the US syndicate boss is seen examining and lovingly touching a winged keel on their yacht - implying that it was a US invention.  In reality, it was the winged keel, invented by Australian Ben Lexcen, that was fitted to the Australian challenging yacht and contributed to her capture of the cup.  The America's Cup was also not lost due to a misjudged turn by the defending skipper, as the film implies - it was lost by 5 races to 4 due to the superior skills and technology of the Australian team.  The US boat was simply outraced.Similarly, the cup was won back by the US in the next race, but not by the use of a "secret weapon" spinnaker (illegal according to the rules anyway) or an innovative hull design, but simply by good sailing on the part of the US team.  The writers were so concerned with fabricating a love story and creating dramatic situations that they sacrificed the genuine drama and excitement of the race.  They made suspension of disbelief impossible by rewriting historical facts, and that's just plain bad film making."Wind" could have been so much more, and in the hands of a good director the flaws in the script could have been reduced, unfortunately Carroll Ballard was not up to the task.  Full marks to the cinematographer, however, for some spectacular shots of yacht racing.
summary: The yacht wins, the film loses
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's been more then a decade since this sleeper cult hit was in the theaters and an equally long period of time that this film was only available on VHS and Laserdisc.Now, at long last, the wait is over!Wind appeals for a number of reasons.Primarily its a very human story of ambition, competition, love, loss, and redemption.  What makes the film work is fantastic photography/camerawork by Mata Yamamoto, a soaring/pumping soundtrack by Basil Poledouris, and a compelling drama played out by some very brainy characters played by some very good actors.Think of it as "The Cutting Edge" and "Strictly Ballroom" with a little more testosterone and in a sailboat!The DVD is pretty bare-bones, but a Digital Widescreen Hi-Definition Remastering and Dolby surround make up for it.  A Special Edition would have been nice, but, considering how long we had to pray for this one it's hardly required.
summary: 1 of the 10 best Sports Event Movies EVER... On DVD AT LAST!
Title: N/A

reviewText: ...that they secretly love this movie. Despite its cheesy, Hollywood take on the America's Cup and its retelling of Dennis Conner's adventures 'on-the-other-side-of-the-pizza'  this movie is not only beautiful eye-candy but more importantly it is exactly what they say in the movie: its good, clean fun.If you're trying to get friends and family intersted in taking a sail, this is one of the best tools to get the blood following -- yup, there are a lot of yachts, but there is the scene with the 14s.  Enough excitement to dispell the idea of sailing as a laid-back sport.For the AC die-hards, its a chance to see the 12-meters in action once again, to hear the legendary PJ Montgomery comment on the races and read the tech/advisory credits which reads like a AC who's who list.  So it isn't "real" or even possible (the 'whumper' is what kills it for some) but after all, you're looking at a movie.  Enjoy it for what it is and appreciate the fact that this movie is the product of a love of sailing!
summary: Even the hard-core AC snobs and fanatics will admit --
Title: N/A

reviewText: No matter what venue this film has come in, video, dvd, blueray (soon, I hope), this film is a classic. It is the classic boy meets girl, boy wins girl, then boy looses girl because he doesn't fight for her. This beautiful young Matt Modine, looses the World cup sailing with his mentor, who of course, is the real culprit in the failure, then calls all his sailing buddies back to make a try at it again......and then.....it is amazing to see how he and his former girlfriend (who is now an amazing engineer) along with her current partner (who is also a genius engineer) work with Modine and his sailor buddies, to actually build a sailboat out in the desert. This is a beautiful film and incredibly inspiring...mixing the diametrically opposite locales, going to the desert to build a sailboat...I have watched this film probably more than twenty times, and it never fails to make me smile, and gives me one of those deep, deep sighs of satisfaction when it finishes. I highly recommend this classic.

You don't have to love the ocean--this movie will take you there. As heartlifting as Rocky or Strictly Ballroom, it's a movie to keep around for whenever you're feeling down, or old.

reviewText: Wind is an absolutely MUST HAVE for all sailing enthusiast.  Great insight into the world of the Americas Cup, when it was a game of skill and design.  Cliff Robertson's character is outstanding as a composite of a few real life America's Cup Skippers of yesteryear.I highly recommend this film to all sailors young and old
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this disk primarily to watch the American Cup sailing.  The movie illustrates how competitive and how hard it is to become a crewmember on one of these boats.  It also illustrates the sexism in the competitive sailing community at this time.  The movie asks whether a woman should sacrifice her dreams for the guy that she loves.  The woman is played by Jennifer Gray and she is a delightfully tough cookie.  Is her boyfriend sensitive enough to her feelings?  Probably not.  He's obsessed with following his own dream.  Anybody interested in sailing or romance should enjoy this movie.

reviewText: I really like this movie. It's one of those movies you watch on a calm sunday morning and it has Jennifer Grey in it!

reviewText: To start out with, like other reviewers have stated, it is terrific to see this movie out on DVD after so long.  I realized, when I watched this movie for the first time, you don't have to be a fan of boat racing to love this movie.The cinematography just can't be beat with absolutely wonderful shots putting you dead center in the action. It's a great experience in how the filmmakers shoot you back and forth onto the boats and then create sweeping panoramic views of strategic boat maneuvers.  Top notch sailboat racing, bar none.The DVD is remastered in high definition and is crystal clear with superb detail and color.  As for sound, Dolby 5.1 or DTS would have been the icing on the cake but I won't sell this DVD short.  The Dolby Surround it does have still gets the job done just fine and sounds excellent.You can't go wrong with Wind and I recommend this movie to anyone who likes great racing and sporting competition.

reviewText: I usually have a problem with movies that have as the subject something I know a lot about. For that reason, I avoided this movie when it came out. I watched it for the first time last night. The technical aspects were very good, the story was plausible and I really enjoyed it. There were a few minor issues that struck me but they were not big issues. In the 1983 Cup, the Australian boat had a winged keel, which was concealed as long as possible. This was a rating issue as the 12 meter is a flexible design class. If you can design a better boat within the rating parameters, you can win races. A winged keel has wings that incline down at about a 30 degree angle. When the boat heels, the leeward wing is deeper into the water, and the windward wing is near horizontal, giving greater lift and less turbulence. The winglets on 737 airliners are a similar design. Aeronautical engineering is very closely related to sailboat design. There is an annual meeting in Las Vegas called "The Ancient Interface." The reason for the name is that sailboats have two foils (or "wings") immersed in different liquids. The sails are in air and the keel and rudder are in water. The "interface" is the surface of the water. The fact that the movie had Kate be an engineer was very authentic. The only quibble is that, in 1983, the American boat did not have a winged keel.The sailing photography was excellent. I was in Freemantle for the 1987 Cup series. The early scene where they were drifting along with no wind is good sailing scripting except that it doesn't apply to Freemantle. Every day, about 11 am, the wind comes in and is called the "Freemantle doctor." Before the wind comes in, it is hot and muggy; when the wind arrives, it blows 30 knots the rest of the day. We were on a spectator boat that was about 150 feet long. I saw green water coming over the bridge, 50 feet in the air. The conditions were wild, which is why Dennis Conner trained his crew in Hawaii. It's the only place in the US with conditions like Freemantle.I wish the 12 meters were back and the crews more amateur than they are now. Until that happens, this is the best alternative.
summary: A great sailing movie (and that is rare)

reviewText: Had forgotten how great the sailing shots are...lived in Newport when the America's Cup was run there and it wasA wild time with the influx of Aussies and the rest of the field...met Ted Turner and crew. Was sad to hear the cup was lost..now run in San Francisco but Newport has more history and style..Californians are not appreciative of much and have terrible taste..look who they elect! I digress...lol..sailed in Newport and watched the tall ships..this movie brings back all the excitement...happy I found it! hIGHLY recommend!

reviewText: As I grow older I notice that I am concentrating on watching the acting more than the story in movies. It was thus in viewing this movie. Matthew Modine is great in everything he does (What the Deaf Man Heard is my favorite). This movie is about the rather sweet love story between a young man and a young woman and his desire to be with her almost constantly. He has been chosen to be second on a yachting crew by and eccentric millionaire(Cliff Robertson) who will command the ship.  They are after the Americas' Cup. Since he is second in command, the young man, puts the girl on the crew, where their affection for one another irritates a crew member and she is axed from the team. She leaves to go on with her life, frustrated by all the obsessions connected with running the perfect race. What the team members do not understand is that she brought special design knowledge to the project. She has made a study of aerodynamics in aircraft design and has been applying them to watercraft as a side interest. The team loses the Americas' Cup to Austrailia and the captain disolves the crew.  Matthew Modine's character becomes convinced he can build a better yacht and captain it himself for the next competition to take the trophy from the Aussies. He searches out his long gone girlfriend for her design help and gets together financing for his project. Since he is captain of the crew, he then puts his female friend on it. When the race is on and disasters keep happening one after another, she is able to figure out the next moves where no one else can. The standout of this movie are the overhead shots during all of the races, the fluid beauty of the neck and neck racing shots. Nothing like it has ever been accomplished before. Matthew Modine is great, and very young  looking in this movie.  Exciting edge of your seat yacht racing.
summary: "I Come Like Water and Like Wind I Go" fr "The Rubiat"
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although the sailing scenes include some of the best fictional footage I've seen, this is one of the silliest stories in moviedom. "Wind" forces hard core sailors to suffer through hours of quasi-romantic drivel to view 10 to 15 minutes of pseudo-America's Cup racing.I recently rewatched one of the sailing scenes while channel surfing.  What started out as a pretty sailboat cool race with both yachts beating to the windwdward mark in high winds and heavy seas.  It then degenerates when a crew member is hoisted to the top of the mast to fix a mainsail whose luff had torn out of the mast (in some camera shots and not in others).  Now how would one man, even Aronold Schwartzenegger, do that all by himself in high wind?  Just grab it and put it back in?  If you've ever been near a wildly luffing mainsail on a 60 foot mast in high wind you'd know it was mpossible.  The credible (and quicker) procedure would have been to drop and re-hoist the mainsail or, if necessary, a replacement sail.But that wouldn't have provided the psychodrama that the writers were shooting for.  Naturally the crew member gets badly hurt while up there, demonstrating both poor judgment and lack of compassion on the part of the bad dad and skipper (Cliff Robertson).This romantic fantasy strains credulity in alomost every imaginable way.  Will the America's Cup skipper reunite with his lady love?  Will her rich nasty dad come through in the pinch and support their America's Cup team?A man who knows nothing about sailing designs, in short order and on a shoestring budget, an America's Cup winner in the desert?  The daughter designs breakthrough sails of nylon when competitors are using kevlar and other hi-tech materials?  The crew pulling an all-nighter on the eve of the final race and marching across town at dawn to step their spare mast on the opponent's boat?  After all, doesn't love conquer all?The love quadrangle (a triangle isn't good enough?) is formulaic and the romantic scenes laughably lyrical.

reviewText: If there ever was a movie waiting to be turned into a DVD WIND has to be it.The maritime Chariots of Fire story is complemented by a great cast of quirky characters and amazing photography. It's beautiful. I almost bought the VHS version years ago but decided to wait. VHS can't do the film justice, especially on my 12' projection screen.

reviewText: Some of the sailing footage is fun to watch. My favorite is the 14's racing in Newport. The love story part of the film is silly and its adaptation to a sailing context is strained, but where the movie very  seriously loses it, in my view, is in the weird depiction of  "technical" aspects of sailing. For the most part, this is  downright embarrassing.The funniest is when they come up with the  innovative "whomper" sail. I have heard non-racers comment on the  movie to the effect of "Why didn't the other racers think of that  sail?" to which the answer is, of course: "It's against the  rules." But I have to thank "Wind" for coming up with my  favorite nick-name for asymetrical spinnakers!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Having read the reviews but never having heard of this film I expected another over-rated B-grade throwaway but was astounded to find that the five star reviews are spot-on.  Excellent in every respect.  The only way this film could have been better was if it had gotten all the permissions necessary to make a more faithful and accurate docu-drama.  Given that the names have been changed, this film is an astounding accomplishment.  The best that can be said is that my wife, who doesn't swim and who only likes sailing when the engine is running, there's no wind, and the water is perfectly flat, loved this movie, not only for the romance story but for the excitement of the sailing action as well.
summary: It's all true!  An excellent film!

reviewText: A friend of mine told me I might like this film, and man was he right. The only film I wanted on DVD was WIND. Had it been available I would have bought my DVD player a year earlier. I've always found this is a great film for inspiration for people who build things; in my case: software. Design, testing, manufacturing, use, competition -- all done in glorous colour, magnificent sea scenery, beautiful boats, helpful commentary, and exceptional musical score. But until March 2003, my VHS copy's low resolution made it revolting to play in my home theatre's 10' screen. I'm so happy.
Title: N/A
